April 15, 2012: Fiction
LOVER REBORN, by J. R. Ward. (New American Library, $27.95.) Book 10 of the
Black Dagger Brotherhood series.
GUILTY WIVES, by James Patterson and David Ellis. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Four
friends in Monte Carlo for a luxurious girls’ vacation find themselves in prison,
accused of a crime.
BETRAYAL, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte Press, $28.) A happy and successful
Hollywood director discovers that someone is embezzling large sums of her money.
STAY CLOSE, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) A disappearance in Atlantic City
brings together three frustrated people whose lives were once connected.
ELEGY FOR EDDIE, by Jacqueline Winspear. (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.) In
1933, Maisie Dobbs, psychologist and investigator, discovers national ramifications
as she probes the death of a London costermonger.
LONE WOLF, by Jodi Picoult. (Emily Bestler/Atria, $28.) The children of a man who
studies wolves must make difficult decisions when he is seriously injured in an
accident.
KILL SHOT, by Vince Flynn. (Emily Bestler/Atria, $27.99.) A C.I.A. super-agent
hunting down perpetrators of the Pan Am Lockerbie bombing, finds himself caught
in a dangerous trap.
THE THIEF, by Clive Cussler and Justin Scott. (Putnam, $27.95.) Isaac Bell tries to
save scientists from German spies.
PRIVATE GAMES, by James Patterson and Mark Sullivan. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
Peter Knight pursues a murderer who is trying to destroy the London Olympics.
DEFENDING JACOB, by William Landay. (Delacorte, $26.) An assistant district
attorney’s life is shaken when his 14-year-old son is accused of murder.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) After a
colossal battle, the Seven Kingdoms face new threats; Book 5 of "A Song of Ice and
Fire."
FORCE OF NATURE, by C. J. Box. (Putnam, $25.95.) A commander from Nate
Romanowski’s old black-ops military unit attacks Nate by going after his friend Joe
Pickett, a Wyoming game warden, and his family.
11/22/63, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $35.) A teacher travels back to 1958 by way
of a time portal in a Maine diner. His assignment is to stop Lee Harvey Oswald.
PHANTOM, by Ted Bell. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The counterspy Alex
Hawke chases a scientist obsessed with cyberwarfare.
April 15, 2012
Non-Fiction
DRIFT, by Rachel Maddow. (Crown, $25.) America’s path to war has become too
easy, with excessive power ceded to the executive branch, the MSNBC host
argues.
THE BIG MISS, by Hank Haney. (Crown Archetype, $26.) The golf coach’s
memoir describes his six eventful years with Tiger Woods.
IMAGINE, by Jonah Lehrer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) An account of the
science of creativity argues that it is not a gift but a thought process that can be
learned.
THE POWER OF HABIT, by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $28.) A Times
reporter’s account of the science behind how we form, and break, habits.
AMERICAN SNIPER, by Chris Kyle with Scott McEwen and Jim DeFelice.
(Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99.) A member of the Navy SEALs discusses his
battlefield experiences.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The heart-
stopping events surrounding the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail.
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
QUIET, by Susan Cain. (Crown, $26.) Introverts — one-third of the population —
are undervalued in American society.
SOLDIER DOGS, by Maria Goodavage. (Dutton, $26.95.) Dogs play an
increasingly vital role in the country’s military efforts; this account emphasizes the
relationship between the animals and their handlers.
THE RIGHTEOUS MIND, by Jonathan Haidt. (Pantheon, $28.95.) A psychologist
argues that people make decisions based on moral intuitions, which makes them
attack opponents self-righteously.
THINKING, FAST AND SLOW, by Daniel Kahneman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$30.) The winner of the Nobel in economic science discusses how we make
choices in business and personal life and when we can and cannot trust our
intuitions.
